titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Ralph Payne, Baron Lavington Papers
titlestmt.author: by Diane J. Ducharme

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday January 22, 2019 at 06:49
profiledesc.descrules: translation missing: en.enumerations.resource_finding_aid_description_rules.beinecke manuscript unit archival processing manual

did.unittitle: Ralph Payne, Baron Lavington family papers

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The papers document the West Indian portions of the economic fortunes and political career of the sugar planter and politician Ralph Payne, first Baron Lavington.

langmaterial.language: Almost entirely in English; some of the official land records are in Law Latin.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from the William Reese Company on the James Marshall and Marie-Louise Osborn Fund, 1999.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Ralph Payne, Baron Lavington Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Ralph Payne, Baron Lavington Papers. James Marshall and Marie-Louise Osborn Collection, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research. Oversize and Parchment Oversize material in boxes 17-18 may be consulted only with permission of the appropriate curator. In some cases, conservation work to an item may be necessary before the item can be consulted. Restricted Fragile in box 19 may be consulted only with permission of the appropriate curator. Preservation photocopies have been substituted in the main files.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Descriptions of some items and groups of material were obtained and/or adapted from descriptions supplied by the dealer or written by curatorial assistants for the Osborn Collection.

relatedmaterial.head: Associated Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Related material may be found in the Lavington Papers: Stuart Documents and in the Osborn Files, located at the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library; the Payne Family Papers, located at the University of British Columbia; several collections in the British Library and the National Library of Ireland; and the Limerick University Library. Several items relating to Lord Lavington are cataloged in The Beinecke Lesser Antilles Collection at Hamilton College by Samuel J. and Penelope R. O. Hough (University Press of Florida, 1994)

bioghist.head: RALPH PAYNE, BARON LAVINGTON (1739-1807)
bioghist.p: Ralph Payne was born in Basseterre, St. Kitts, in 1739, the surviving son of Ralph Payne (d. 1763), chief justice of St. Kitts, and his first wife Alice Carlisle, the only surviving child and heiress of the Antiguan planter Francis Carlisle.

Like many of the West Indian elite, Payne divided his time between England, especially London, and the Caribbean plantations from which he derived his wealth and power. Educated at Christ's Hospital, Payne returned to Antigua in 1759, where he was promptly elected to the House of Assembly and unanimously voted Speaker of the House.

Payne returned to England in 1762 and embarked on a lengthy and expensive Grand Tour of Europe. In 1767 he married Françoise Lambertina Kölbel, daughter of Henry, Baron Kölbel of Saxony; she was a close friend of Queen Charlotte. Shortly after his marriage, Payne entered English politics, and was M.P. for Shaftesbury from 1768 until 1771, when he was made Knight of the Order of the Bath and set sail for Antigua as the newly-appointed Governor-General of the Leeward Islands.

Payne was popular with the plantation owners. He supported Lord North's government in its struggles with the North American colonists, reporting in 1774 that his islands were free of "mischievous sparks of the Continental flame." He was the first governor in over fifty years to visit every one of the Leeward Islands, after the "Great Hurricane" of 1772. (At the time, the colony consisted of Antigua, Barbuda, the British Virgin Islands, Montserrat, St. Christopher's (St. Kitts), Nevis, Anguilla and Dominica.) He also patronized the artist Thomas Hearne. In 1775, the Paynes left for England "to reestablish Lady Payne's health," and the Assembly petitioned for his speedy return and presented him with a diamond-encrusted sword as a token of their affection. Payne was to remain in England for the next twenty-four years.

He spent many years in various elective and appointive offices, becoming a supporter of Fox after 1780. Payne and his wife also became known for their elaborate parties, despite the rumored unhappiness of their marriage. In 1788 he traveled again on the Continent, and conducted secret but unsuccessful negotiations with Charlotte, Duchess of Albany over the possible return of the Stuart crown jewels to England.

Payne, whose wealth was declining rapidly due to his lavish spending and to the sharp decline of sugar profits after the American Revolution, seceded from the Whig Club and allied with William Pitt and Henry Dundas. In fact, the dinner at which Dundas and Lord Loughborough first broached the idea of an alliance between Pitt and the Duke of Portland was held at his Grafton Street house. His reward for changing parties followed quickly; he was created Baron Lavington of Lavington in the Irish peerage in October 1795.

In 1799 he was re-appointed Governor-General of the Leeward Islands, and arrived in Antigua in August, 1801. He moved into the just-completed Government House, and remained on that island until his death in August, 1807. Payne was buried on Carlisles, his Antigua plantation. His estate was thoroughly encumbered by debts, mortgages, and liferents, and his widow was left so poor that the Antiguan assembly voted her a pension of L 300 a year "in affection and esteem." She returned soon after to England, and died at Hampton Court Palace in 1830. See "Payne, Ralph, Baron Lavington" in the Oxford Dictionary of National Biography (Oxford, 2004) for further information.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Ralph Payne, Baron Lavington Papers document the West Indian portions of the economic fortunes and political career of the sugar planter and politician Ralph Payne, first Baron Lavington. The researcher will also find the papers of value in the study of the history of the Caribbean sugar trade, including documentation of land and slave ownership and estate management in the West Indies. While the record of Payne's holdings is far from complete, his papers reveal the dense networks of family and patronage connections that operated in the Caribbean colonies in the later eighteenth century. The papers span the dates 1689-1855, but the bulk of the material dates from 1730 to 1790. The collection is organized into six series: Correspondence; Political and Governmental Papers; Land and Plantation Records; Payne Family Personal Estate Papers; Other Business Papers; and Accounts, Bills and Receipts. Boxes 16-17 contain Oversize material. Oversize Broadside Material is housed in a separate location.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series I, Correspondence , is organized into four subseries: Sir Ralph Payne (d. 1763?), Ralph Payne, Baron Lavington (1739-1808), Stephen Payne (d. 1772?), and Third Party Correspondence. Within each subseries letters are arranged alphabetically by correspondent, with unidentified letters placed at the end. The series includes correspondence of Ralph Payne and of various family members, including his father and his uncle, Stephen Payne. The first subseries, Sir Ralph Payne (d. 1763) contains mostly single business letters from overseers, tenants, debtors, and sugar factors to the father of Ralph Payne, Baron Lavington. The letters of Alexander Cooper, who was the elder Payne's partner in the establishment of a sugar plantation on St. Croix, contain precise details about that operation, covering everything from a lack of copper for boilers and the high price of salt beef to an epidemic among the slaves. A 1753 letter describes the practice of giving sick slaves "their liberty" on the Spanish Main. Other topics in this subseries include the difficulty of collecting debts; the shipment of sugar to New York and London; and plantation conditions. Discussion of individual slaves and slave management practices occurs throughout the letters. W. Thomas's comprehensive offer to sell his estate to Payne includes a request to exclude several slaves from the sale at "my wife's desire that the family shall not be separated." The second subseries, Ralph Payne, Baron Lavington, primarily consists of brief business notes concerning bills of exchange, letters of credit, and appointments. Most correspondents are represented by fewer than five letters. There are two folders of lengthy letters from Edward Jones, who was apparently overseer of Payne's plantations on Antigua, containing details of many slave sales; sugar prices and production difficulties; the effects of the naval war on shipping in the Leeward Islands; and other business matters. Several 1799 letters discuss the suitability of Government House as Payne's official residence and other preparations for his arrival in Antigua. Folders 65-70 contain the letters of Godschall Johnson, another Antigua planter with substantial business interests in England who spent years in London. Most of these letters were written while Payne was traveling on the Continent in 1787-88, and contain reports requested by Payne on his sugar plantations, shipping arrangements and finances; information on bills of exchange, annuities, mortgages, and other business dealings among members of the interconnected Payne, Ottley, Willett, Adye, and Payne-Gallwey families of St. Kitts and Antigua; and some personal news. The Stephen Payne subseries includes a group of lengthy letters from bibliophile and St. Kitts native Ralph Willett, located in folders 101-112. Written during the 1760s, the letters document Willett's extensive business interests on St. Kitts, particularly the problems of absentee estate management, including sugar production, plantation maintenance, unreliable overseers, and chronically indebted renters. Willett also sends news of and comments on various relatives, including Ralph Payne, Baron Lavington himself. A March 25, 1763 letter, written shortly after Sir Ralph Payne's death, points out that his son "makes, for a young man, a great sacrifice in leaving England" to manage his inheritance on St. Kitts. Willett's unsuccessful attempts to arrange a marriage for the dowerless cousin Nancy Payne are also discussed in detail, as are various business dealings, inheritances, and debts among Willett's family connections. The remainder of the subseries consists of mostly routine business letters addressed to Stephen Payne, who was an uncle of Ralph Payne and one of his agents and accountants. At least two of the 1763 letters mention Ralph Payne's recent death. Third Party Correspondence contains letters to recipients other than the main members of the Payne family. They concern business and legal matters. The letters of Judith Butler Dunbar concern the settlement of a relative's estate.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series II, Political and Governmental Records, is organized into four chronological and topical subseries: Member of the Assembly (1759-1761); First Governorship of the Leeward Islands (1771-1775); Tortola Dispute Papers; and Second Governorship of the Leeward Islands (1799-1807). The series documents the West Indian portion of Ralph Payne, Baron Lavington's political career. It contains no records related to his service in the British Parliament. The first subseries, Member of the Assembly, contains several documents from Payne's first office holding as a member of the House of Assembly. These relate to the dissatisfaction of the Leeward islanders with the British military's abandonment of an attack on Martinique in 1759, and include "A Transliteration from the French of a Letter from the Inhabitants of a Neighboring Island to ------." This is a satire in which the inhabitants of Martinique supposedly thank Sir John Moore for relieving them against the interests of Great Britain, and rehearse all of the Leeward Islanders' complaints. There are also documents relating to the official inquiry into Moore's conduct, apparently abandoned after his successful capture of Guadeloupe in March of 1760. The second subseries, "First Governorship of the Leeward Islands (1771-1776) primarily concerns Payne's departure from Antigua on a leave in 1775 and include the official grant of his leave by George III, a copy of his farewell speech to the Legislature and the legislature's petition for his return. Folder 134 contains a copy of "Queries Relating to his Majesty's Islands in America," a 1773 survey sent to Caribbean governors by Lord Dartmouth. Tortola Dispute Papers, housed in folders 138-145, document parts of a frequent type of conflict over land ownership and property rights in the Caribbean colonies, stemming from what Lavington refers to as "the usurpation of property arising from the lawless state of the country." In this case, the Governor's demand that the Tortolans produce their title deeds and letters patent resulted in a long and bitter dispute over the existence and authenticity of such documentation, as rival claims and duplicate title documents, some apparently forged or issued in error, were entered into evidence. The documents include Lavington's statement concerning his conduct in the matter, particularly in the case of John Fahie, and a letter from Fahie denouncing the Tortolans and the Assembly of the Virgin Islands and adding details of the islanders' fight against the title demand.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series III, Land and Plantation Records , contains deeds, royal warrants, mortgages, leases, official inventories, quitclaims, wills, annuity grants, articles of purchase, and other conveyance documents concerning properties on various Caribbean islands. These have been arranged first by island, then by property name, and finally chronologically within each property. Documents relating to properties on multiple islands have been listed at the beginning of the series. Information concerning the persons named in a document has been provided wherever it was readily available, whether from a docket or from the document text. In most cases, we do not have a complete title series for any given property, nor is it always clear why a specific document is found in the Lavington Papers, although in many cases a member of the Payne family or a related family is named. Nevertheless, these provide valuable information concerning West Indian plantation ownership and business dealings. Many of the documents are or contain detailed inventories: there are at least sixteen slave inventories in this series, from several islands across seven decades. Occasionally there is a fairly full accounting of the history of a property. Box 5, folders 150-161 contains documents relating to Carlisles, once one of the richest plantations on Antigua, from an early inventory of "field negroes" to the legal maneuvering that resulted in Baron Lavington's eventual inheritance of the property, to the multiple "sales of Negroes" in the 1790s that financed Lavington in London. (The final mortgage on Carlisles is located in Box 5, folder 150). The largest number of documents is from Lavington's native St. Kitts. Many from the 1720s relate to the final expulsion of the French from St. Kitts by the Treaty of Utrecht and the British crown's attempt to regularize land titles in the conquered area of Basseterre: hence the many "articles of purchase" between island residents and "His Majesty." Indentures and rental agreements for smaller plantations on both St. Kitts and Nevis also contain valuable information about the economic and social status of non-slaveholding white settlers, while the mortgage and annuity contracts reveal the often ruinous loan terms agreed to by cash-poor owners. Folders 178-180 contain documents related to the St. Croix sugar plantation founded by Ralph Payne and Alexander Cooper.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series IV contains documents relating to the settlement of the wills and legacies of members of the Payne family, particularly Sir Ralph Payne (d. 1763) and Ralph Payne, Baron Lavington. Folder 237 contains a detailed list of slaves owned by Lord Lavington and their planned dispositions on his death.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series V, Other Business Papers , is organized alphabetically by type of material and then chronologically within each type. Contents include seven appraisals or slaves, stock and other properties; a variety of financial contracts; a declaration of manumission; and a set of documents relating to a prolonged legal dispute over lands on Nevis from the 1750s. Many of these papers also concern members of the Payne, Payne-Gallwey, Ottley, and Adye families documented elsewhere in the collection.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series VI, Accounts, Bills and Receipts, is divided into four subseries: Ralph Payne (d. 1763); Ralph Payne, Baron Lavington (1739-1807); Stephen Payne (d. 1772); and Other Accounts.The first three are chronologically arranged; the items have been roughly sorted by year. This series contains a wealth of information on all types of financial transactions, from bills of exchange through a 1752 receipt for "30 fine brilliant diamonds" and for "building the steps to the organ Loft" for a church in St. Kitts. The "accounts of sundries" frequently contain information on the purchase of individual slaves, listed alongside farming and sugarmaking supplies and "sundries from London." In addition to the above types of information, the accounts of Ralph Payne, Baron Lavington also include information on his expenditures during his governorships. The folders of receipts and bills covering his sojourn in England, although obviously very incomplete, document his aristocratic tastes in clothing, food and household goods as well as his increasing indebtedness and frequent inability to raise small sums of cash. Stephen Payne's accounts are more tightly focused on his work as a manager and overseer for his more prosperous relatives. "Other Accounts" contains single items and small groups of financial records related to individuals, almost all of whom did business with Stephen Payne. They have been left in the order in which they were received, filed by personal name.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The material in Box 18 may be seen only with the permission of the appropriate curator. In some cases, conservation work to an item may be necessary before the item can be consulted.
